a. for the risk insured, You have never had any insurance terminated in the last twelve (12) months due solely or in part to a breach of any premium payment condition; or
    b. if You have declared that You have breached any premium payment condition in respect of a previous policy taken up with another insurer in the last twelve (12) months:
        i. You have fully paid all outstanding premium for time on risk calculated by the previous insurer based on the customary short period rate in respect of the previous policy; and
        ii. a copy of the written confirmation from the previous insurer to this effect is first provided by You to Us before cover incepts.
questions: How does the insurer handle coverage eligibility if the insured has had a previous insurance policy terminated within the last twelve months due to non-payment of premiums, and what documentation is required to reinstate coverage?
What are the conditions under which an insured who has breached premium payment terms on a prior policy can still obtain coverage, and how must outstanding premiums be settled and verified?
In cases where the insured declares a breach of premium payment condition on a previous policy, what timing and documentation requirements must be met before the new coverage begins?

How does the insurer verify that all outstanding premiums from a previous insurer have been fully paid when the insured has breached premium payment conditions, and what impact does this have on the inception of the new policy?
What is the significance of the customary short period rate in calculating outstanding premiums owed to a previous insurer, and how does this affect the insured's eligibility for new coverage?
If an insured fails to provide written confirmation from a previous insurer regarding premium payment status, what are the implications for the commencement of coverage under the new policy?

How does the insurer treat cases where the insured has never had any insurance terminated due to premium payment breaches in the last twelve months, in terms of risk assessment and coverage eligibility?
What are the insurer's requirements for the insured to declare any breaches of premium payment conditions from previous policies, and how does this declaration affect the underwriting process?

How does the insurer's policy address situations where the insured has partially paid outstanding premiums to a previous insurer but lacks written confirmation, and what are the consequences for coverage inception?
What role does the timing of premium payments and the provision of written confirmation from previous insurers play in determining when coverage under the new policy can begin?
How does the insurer's condition regarding premium payment breaches interact with general exclusions related to non-disclosure or misrepresentation in the application process?
In what ways might the requirement for written confirmation from a previous insurer before coverage inception create challenges for insureds switching insurers, and how can these be mitigated?
How does the insurer's policy ensure that risks associated with previous premium payment breaches are managed before accepting new coverage, and what are the safeguards against repeated breaches?

What are the implications for an insured who has had multiple insurance policies terminated for premium payment breaches within the last twelve months, and how does this affect their eligibility under this policy?
How does the insurer define 'breach of any premium payment condition,' and how might different interpretations impact claims and coverage eligibility?
What documentation must the insured provide to demonstrate compliance with premium payment conditions from previous insurers, and how does this documentation affect the underwriting timeline?
How does the insurer handle situations where the insured disputes the amount of outstanding premium calculated by the previous insurer based on the customary short period rate?
What are the consequences if the insured fails to disclose a breach of premium payment conditions from a previous policy, and how does this interact with policy-wide general exclusions?
How does the insurer's requirement for full payment of outstanding premiums before coverage inception align with common industry practices regarding premium payment breaches and reinstatements?

In cases where the insured has had a previous policy terminated due to premium payment breaches but has since rectified the situation, how does the insurer assess the risk and determine coverage terms?
